Award.AwardTitle: Coupled Mixing and Auto-Ignition Dynamics of Turbulent Fuel Jets Issuing into Hot and Vitiated Oxidizing Environments

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1605136 - Sutton

A broad range of engineering systems such as transportation and power-generation platforms rely on the injection of a turbulent fuel stream into a high-temperature, oxidizing environment. Under certain mixture and temperature conditions, auto-ignition will occur. Systems such as diesel engines and high-speed scramjets/ramjets rely on auto-ignition for achieving ignition and flame stabilization. Other systems, including gas-turbine and spark-ignition engines are designed to prevent auto-ignition to avoid significant and/or catastrophic damage. For either of these scenarios it is highly desired to understand the physics governing the transient auto-ignition process. Turbulent flows are very complex and when coupled to the chemical reactions governing auto-ignition, a highly dynamic system is formed where turbulent mixing has a direct effect on the reaction chemistry. In this project, time-resolved measurements of fuel/oxidizer mixing, temperature, and species will be made using advanced laser diagnostics, characterizing the flow and chemical conditions necessary for achieving auto-ignition kernel formation under turbulent fuel injection. The impact of the research will be far-reaching, ranging from a new physical understanding of auto-ignition dynamics to assessing numerical simulations and models. This project also will aid in the training of a graduate student and mentoring of a post-doctoral researcher. In addition, a unique aspect of this project is the implementation of a formal direct graduate-to-undergraduate mentoring program, where a graduate student is partnered with and mentors an undergraduate honors student. The PI also will partner with a local elementary school for K-12 outreach, equipping young students with information, inspiration, and initiative in STEM-related topics. The overarching topics, such as combustion, engines, and lasers, provide exciting themes for younger children and can help build the foundation for a life-long interest in science and technology.

The proposed research will be transformative in the fact that the dynamic coupling between turbulent mixing, low-temperature chemistry and ?hot? ignition kernel formation will be examined in detail for the first time. High-speed (10 to 100 kHz acquisition rate) laser diagnostics will be used to measure the mixture fraction, temperature, and CH2O/OH concentrations following turbulent fuel injection through auto-ignition. Specific research contributions include quantification of key time-dependent processes which lead to the observed auto-ignition topology including the mechanisms in with turbulent mixing modifies auto-ignition topology and the role of low-temperature chemistry (e.g., CH2O) on ignition kernel formation. Due to the transient and spatially-intermittent nature of the auto-ignition process, multi-dimensional, temporal records are necessary to characterize the flow field scalars at the ignition kernel sites. These measurements will be used to determine space-time correlations between mixture fraction, CH2O (low-temperature chemistry) and OH (hot ignition kernel) as well develop new statistics of the mixture fraction, temperature, and scalar dissipation conditioned on the ignition kernel location for parameterization of the most probable conditions leading to auto-ignition. The proposed measurements will be carried out across a broad range of test conditions, examining the effects of varying Reynolds (Damk√∂hler) number, fuel type, and oxidizer composition and temperature.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The mixing and subsequent auto-ignition of a turbulent fuel stream issuing into a hot (and vitiated) oxidizing environment is of significant interest in the fluid and thermal sciences due to its importance in a number of engineering systems. For example, internal combustion engines including diesel or HCCI platforms, energy-conversion systems employing flameless or reheat combustion, and scramjets are examples where auto-ignition is necessary to initiate combustion. Conversely, auto-ignition is to be prevented in spark-ignited (SI) engines, fmaterial storage areas, and mixing ducts of gas turbine combustors, especially lean, premixed, pre-vaporized (LPP) systems, in order to avoid catastrophic damage or high levels of pollutant output.  Over the last several decades, considerable research has been devoted to studying auto-ignition processes under nearly homogeneous and laminar conditions, where the dependence and global sensitivity to thermodynamic conditions such as temperature and pressure have been well documented. However, realistic systems are highly turbulent which leads to mixture non-uniformities and the development of a broad range of length and time scales. Under these circumstances, auto-ignition is governed by a complex coupling between turbulent fluid mechanics, scalar mixing, and chemistry and yields a dynamic system where the mixing has a direct effect on the reaction chemistry. This highlights the need for new experiments for understanding the complex dynamics of auto-ignition processes.

The research supported by this grant focused on measuring the conditions (mixing state, temperature, turbulence level) that facilitate ignition through the use of state-of-the-art high-speed optical and laser diagnostics. Specifically, this research program targeted (i) characterization of the most probable ignition height and time following fuel injection for variations in fuel type, oxidizer temperature, and oxidizer oxygen content and (ii) the development of a new understanding of the relative roles of flow turbulence, fuel-air mixing, and temperature fluctuations on high-temperature ignition.

First, high-speed (20 kHz acquisition rate) imaging was used to identify the location and timing of the formation of ignition kernels, providing visualization of the ignition dynamics and a detailed statistical evaluation of ignition heights and ignition delay. The auto-ignition location and ignition delay times showed a strong sensitivity to coflow temperature with increased sensitivities at lower coflow temperatures. The ignition height was shown to be much more intermittent than the ignition delay time. The effects of fuel dilution were shown to lead to an expected increase in the ignition height, but an unexpected decrease in ignition delay time. A probable reason for the reduction in ignition delay time is the lower Reynolds numbers for the diluted cases wdue to an increase in kinematic viscosity. The lower Reynolds numbers produce flow fields with lower strain and scalar dissipation rate, which is known to inhibit ignition. Finally, the effects of variations in the coflow oxidizer content on ignition properties were found to be noticeable, but still significantly less than variations in the temperature.

Comparisons between kernel formation location for the transient jet and the fluctuating flame base of the subsequent, stabilized lifted flame was performed to examine the role of auto-ignition in flame stabilization over a broad range of temperatures. It was found that for high coflow temperatures, the mean liftoff height of the steady-state flame was significantly closer to the fuel nozzle than the location of the initial ignition kernel formation and the RMS fluctuations were much lower for the steady-state flame as compared to the ignition kernel formation. However, for lower coflow temperatures, the statistics between the initial kernel formation and the fluctuating flame base were almost identical, both in mean position and RMS fluctuation. These results suggest that at lower coflow temperatures, the stabilization mechanism is dominated by auto-ignition, while at higher coflow temperatures, flame propagation plays a key role.

High-speed velocity measurements of the flow field properties were examined during transient fuel injection to determine whether (from a fluid dynamic point of view), impulsively started fuel jets reach steady state prior to the onset of ignition. The results indicate for a large range of conditions, steady-state is achieved, which may simplify certain modeling approaches. In addition, a detailed statistical characterization of the fluid kinematic properties was performed, generating a database in which to understand the most probable conditions (i.e., vorticity, strain rate) that facilitate ignition. Finally, high-speed Rayleigh scattering measurements were performed to simultaneously determine the mixture fraction and temperature fields prior to and at the onset of ignition. The results indicated that ignition occurs at very lean (and high-temperature) conditions for the fuel cases investigated and at mixture fraction values less than the most reactive mixture fraction as determined from 0D homogenous reactor studies. The fact that the most probable mixture fraction at which ignition occurs is less than the most reactive mixture fraction indicates that the local turbulent flow field heavily influences the ignition process, delaying ignition and shifting the location to a much leaner region with minimal turbulence levels.
